moves.7. d5 a5 8. O-O Na6 9. Be3: I think usually h3 is played first in these positions to prevent black's next move.
moves.12... Bd7 13. b4 axb4 14. axb4 Na6 15. N: Using attack on the knight to redeploy my knight to d3 square protecting b4 and working towards c5 push, the plan is to also push f3 and redeploy the dark-squared bishop to f2 to support my c5 push
moves.15... Nh6 16. Nd3 b6: He is aiming to stop my queen-side advance. Perhaps he should've been focusing more on his king-side play.
moves.17. Ra2 Qc8: Good move, his queen works both sides well and also removes the pin and to allow his f5 king-side attack
moves.18. Nb5: Here I started to drift a bit, I wasn't sure how to continue. I figured the knight is very hard to remove and somewhat paralyzes black's queenside pieces and pawns.
moves.18... f5 19. f3 Nf7 20. Bf2: All of white's pieces are now pointing to the queen-side, but black has not managed to organize a king-side attack quite yet
moves.20... c6: I missed this, this was the point of Nf7
moves.21. dxc6 Bxc6 22. Bxb6 Qb7 23. Bf2: Black gets some initiative in the center
moves.23... fxe4 24. fxe4 Bxe4 25. Bf3: Good move, this was the only way that I could see to not lose the pawn
moves.25... Bxf3 26. gxf3 Nc7 27. Rxa8 Rxa8 28: Nice redeployment of the night, narrowing down on the central light squares paralyzing black's centeral pawns and the dark-squared bishop
moves.29. Ne4 d5 30. Nec5 Nxc5 31. Nxc5 Qxb4 3: Pretty shaky position here for me. Luckily tactics worked in my favor here.
moves.32... Rd8 33. Qe6: Keeping the knight pinned is important here
moves.33... Qc3: Attacking f3 and threating my fairly unsafe king.
moves.34. Nb7 Rd3: A mistake. Black must keep white's queen from invading on the back rank. Although it's hard to find a good spot for the rook. If Rb8 then Ba7, if Rf8 then Bc4. Perhaps, Ra8 was the better spot for the rook
moves.37. Bxd6 Rxd6 38. Nxd6 Qd4+ 39. Kg2 Qxd6: So white won an exchange and is better in this end-game, but there is still a lot of work and dangers remain. Qc8 is a good move as it protects the important g4 square.
moves.42... Qe3 43. Qe6+ Kg7: Here I tried lots of different path's but nothing seemed to work as black always had a chance to go into checking frenzy on the white king.
moves.44. Rb2: Good move, it still protects white's 2nd rank from queen's checks and threatens Rb7
moves.44... Qg5+ 45. Qg4 Qxg4+: ?! Making white's job that much easier.
moves.46. fxg4 Kf7: And here a nice final touch
moves.47. Rf2+: Keeping the king stuck in the corner or else blocking the bishop from stopping the white's passed pawn
moves.47... Ke7 48. c5 Ke8 49. Rxf8+: ! This key deflection gives white the one extra move that he needs to penetrate black's position

opening: King's Indian (E92), Petrosian system, Stein variation
